summary: This document is an email chain from January 2020 among U.S. Attorney's Office (SDNY) staff regarding travel approval and logistical arrangements for a team conducting interviews in Stockholm, Sweden, as part of the Epstein investigation (2018R01618). The emails detail flight booking issues, cost concerns, and coordination between legal assistants and prosecutors, revealing ongoing investigative activity months after Epstein's death.

persons.name: Darlene Alleyne
persons.role: Legal Assistant, Public Corruption Unit, U.S. Attorney's Office (SDNY)
persons.context: Primary point of contact for booking travel arrangements for the prosecution team; handles flight and hotel reservations and communicates with team members about itinerary changes and costs.

persons.name: Alex
persons.role: Assistant U.S. Attorney, Southern District of New York
persons.context: Lead prosecutor on the Epstein investigation travel team; requests travel approvals, specifies flight preferences, and coordinates with Darlene Alleyne on logistics for interviews in Stockholm and other locations.

persons.name: Alison
persons.context: Colleague of Alex on the Epstein investigation travel team; her flight itinerary is used as a cost benchmark; she travels with the team for victim interviews.

persons.name: Maurene
persons.context: Colleague of Alex and Alison on the Epstein investigation travel team; travels for victim interviews in West Palm Beach and potentially Stockholm.

persons.name: Edward Tyrrell
persons.role: Supervisory Official (likely Chief of Criminal Division or similar)
persons.context: Approving authority for travel requests related to the Epstein investigation; grants permission for domestic and international trips for the prosecution team.

persons.name: Michele Duncan
persons.context: Copied on travel approval emails; appears to be part of the administrative or supervisory chain.

persons.name: Cynthia Perez
persons.context: Copied on travel approval emails; appears to be part of the administrative or supervisory chain.

persons.name: James Bullock
persons.context: Mentioned as being informed about hotel scheduling during the travel booking process.

connections.description: Alex relies on Darlene to book travel arrangements for the Epstein investigation team, with frequent email exchanges about flight options, costs, and refundability.
Alex requests and receives travel approval from Edward Tyrrell for multiple trips related to the Epstein investigation.
Work together as part of the prosecution team traveling for victim interviews; Alex references Alison's flight schedule when coordinating travel.
Work together as part of the prosecution team traveling for victim interviews, particularly to West Palm Beach.
Copied on internal emails regarding travel arrangements, indicating administrative coordination within the U.S. Attorney's Office.

events.title: Travel to Stockholm for Interview
events.description: The prosecution team (Alex, Alison, and potentially others) travels to Stockholm, Sweden, to conduct an interview related to the Epstein investigation. The trip involves flights from JFK with layovers in Paris.

events.title: Travel to Los Angeles for Interview
events.description: The team requests permission to travel to Los Angeles for an interview (or interviews) related to the Epstein investigation.

events.title: Travel to West Palm Beach for Interview
events.description: Alex and Maurene travel to West Palm Beach, Florida, for an interview related to the Epstein investigation, with a request to reserve a conference room.

events.title: Travel to Los Angeles for Victim Interview
events.description: The team (Alex, Alison, and/or Maurene) requests permission to travel to Los Angeles for a victim interview, with plans to reserve a conference room.

keyFacts: The U.S. Attorney's Office for the Southern District of New York was actively conducting interviews for the Epstein investigation (case 2018R01618) in early 2020, including an international trip to Stockholm, Sweden.

Travel for the investigation required specific approvals, use of refundable flights for international travel, and adherence to government cost guidelines, leading to logistical challenges and internal email disputes.
The prosecution team involved multiple Assistant U.S. Attorneys (Alex, Alison, Maurene) and support staff (Darlene Alleyne), with Edward Tyrrell as the approving official for travel requests.
The emails reference prior investigative travel to Los Angeles and West Palm Beach in 2019 for victim interviews, indicating a sustained, multi-location effort post-Epstein's arrest and death.

The document reveals operational details of federal investigation travel, including the use of government travel agencies (CWT Sato), per diem limits, and the requirement for refundable international tickets.
